title: Kevin Kearney Run Raises $5K For Scholarship - The Wave
text:
Rockaway's Newspaper since 1893 | 718-634-4000 By 

        Angelica Katz    
| 
 on 
        June 20, 2017 From left to right: Sean Kearney, son of Kevin Kearney, John Edwards, organizer of the race, and Matt Centrowitz, two-time Olympian. On the Rockaway boardwalk, supporters gathered from across the country to join hundreds of locals in memory of Kevin Kearney—whose loyalty as a friend, neighbor, father and husband was apparent in the sizable crowd that came together to share his love of running at the Third Annual 5K Kevin Kearney Scholarship/Fundraiser on Saturday, June 17.
“The Kevin Kearney Scholarship Fund sends underprivileged kids to Catholic school in Rockaway,” said John Edwards, organizer of the race and friend of Kearney. “We were lucky the weather turned out in our favor—it’s not good beach weather, but it’s perfect running weather.”
The 5K race in memory of Kearney, who passed away from pancreatic cancer in 2015, works to raise $5K each year for two Rockaway students. Each scholarship winner receives $2,500 from the Kearney scholarship fund toward their school’s tuition.
“He ran in high school, college and then started running on the boardwalk in the 1970s when we moved to Rockaway.  Kevin and John [Edwards] would go out every Saturday morning at 5 a.m. and then started a training series that met on Thursday nights on the boardwalk with 20 or more other runners and kept growing. They were the ones who began all the races here in Rockaway,” said Kearney’s wife, Marybeth Kearney.
Many of Kevin’s longtime friends came out to show their support, including Matthew Centrowitz – a two-time Olympic distance runner and four-time United States champion.
“Kevin was a good friend of mine,” said Centrowitz who presently coaches track at American University.
His son, Matthew Centrowitz, Jr., also an Olympian, won the gold medal in distance running in the last Olympics in Rio de Janeiro. Centrowitz, Jr., also ran in Rockaway’s Rocakpulco running series in 2006 and 2007.
In effort to raise funds for the Kevin Kearney Scholarship Fund, Centrowitz sold autographed copies of his book, “Like Father, Like Son.” The book highlights his experiences training for the Olympics in the early 1980s as well as his journey into fatherhood and becoming a coach for his son.
At the race, which stretched from Beach 102nd Street to Beach 65th Street, runners sported Rockaway Gliders sneakers, which were sold for $40 each to raise additional funds for the Kearney Scholarship fund.
Prior to the Kearney 5K race, the Rockapulco running series hosted a half-marathon with over 100 participants.
“I love the Rockaway running series because everyone is included. I don’t even run— I walk the race—and always look forward to these events,” said Cynthia Freeman.
Kevin Kearney represented the Diocese of Brooklyn for 37 years as an active board member of Concern USA and Mutual of America. Kearney was also a member of the National Association of Diocesean Attorneys, Knight of the Holy Sepulchre, Catholic Charities, the Emerald Society, Futures in Education and the Rockaway Gliders.







				From left to right: Sean Kearney, son of Kevin Kearney; Mary Beth Kearney, wife of Kevin Kearney and Micaela Casey, grand-daughter of Kevin Kearney. Photos by Angelica Katz
				




				The Fajardo Family. From Left to right: Bert, Lisa, Jeanne Moore and Margie.
				




				Brothers, Dennis And Colin Moriarty, participate in Kevin Kearney’s 5K Race/Fundraiser
				




				Caroline Gifford, 3rd overall female, crossed the finish line with a running time of 23:05.

				




				Bert Robbins, 84 years-old—the oldest runner in the race—dashes across the finish line, zipping past runners less than half his age.
